text:
Killing her was supposed to make up for a ton of sins. She was draining the life out of poor people. Was that really a crime? I’m not thinking about it, and I’m tired of everyone throwing it in my face. “A crime! A crime!” Now I see how foolish my cowardice was. I’ve decided to face this unnecessary disgrace. It’s just because I’m weak and have nothing in me that I figured I’d do this, maybe for my own good, like that Porfiry guy suggested! 

“Brother, what are you saying? You’ve shed blood!” Dounia exclaimed, horrified.

“Blood that everyone sheds!” I shot back, almost panicking. “It flows like water, spilled like champagne, and people get honored for it in the Capitol. They’re called benefactors of mankind. Look deeper and get it! I wanted to help people too and would have done a ton of good deeds to make up for that one dumb mistake. Not even dumb, just clumsy. The idea wasn’t as stupid as it seems now that it flopped. Everything looks dumb when it fails, right? I just wanted to be independent, to take that first step, and then everything would’ve been smoothed over by the massive good I could’ve done. But I... I couldn’t even take that first step because I’m weak. That’s the issue! If I had succeeded, I would’ve been a hero, but now I’m stuck.” 

“That’s not true! What are you talking about?” Dounia replied.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist grapples with the moral implications of his actions, justifying his crime as a misguided attempt to achieve a greater good while confronting his own cowardice and contemptibility.
